items.title: Gallery
items.summary: Scenes are everywhere. I love to capture the special ones when I…
items.content_html:
Scenes are everywhere. I love to capture the special ones when I happen to be presented to them.

What I enjoy to capture:

  • Light effect
  • Sky
  • Micro-object (e.g. flowers)

I don't use filters or any post-process in any of my photos. Only modification is crop and resize.

items.title: Veggie Pallet
items.summary: This veggie pallet is made from abandoned pallet picked up on…
items.content_html:
This veggie pallet is made from abandoned pallet picked up on the street. The seeds are germinated from parts of the purchased vegetable!

For example, the spring onions are generated from the white head of the purchased ones.

This is my contribution of a substainable world!

items.title: Interactive Map Scholarship Project
items.summary: What is this map?This interactive map was part of the deliveries of…
items.content_html:
What is this map?

This interactive map was part of the deliveries of my scholarship project, carried out from November 2015 to February 2016, supervised by University of Canterbury Adjunct Fellow and Statistics New Zealand Senior Researcher, Richard Penny, funded by Statistics New Zealand. The purpose of this project was to build an interactive map that shows how people commuted to work on the censused day in New Zealand.

Key features:

  1. Source data was retrieved from Statistics New Zealand website.
  2. Geospatial techniques involved
  3. Data cleansing
  4. Exploratory Data Analysis
  5. Data modelling
  6. One-mean table and map
  7. Two-mean table and map
  8. Interactive Scatterplot

The other deliveries items were a project report and presentation to Statistics New Zealand. Statistics New Zealand has then further developed this topic.

Gain from this project:

  • I learnt how to build a Shiny application during the project by myself.
  • A highly open project with guideline and inspiration provided by top expert, Richard.

Interested? Full presentation PowerPoint is available here. Or click here to explore the application. Thanks Shiny.io for hosting it.

items.title: About Carina
items.content_html:
A Chinese-NewZealander who appreciates life and loves to love.
Has a loving and lovely mum, an energic cat named Bella, faithful friends.
Part-time geeky, full-time magician (that's what they call me at work because I get the jobs done efficiently).
Passionate about Data Science.
Definitely crazy about Squash, languages and Hanfu; interested in gardening, cooking, photographer.

items.title: What I learn from Data + Art STEAM Project
items.summary: One night I was doing project planning and information gathering for my assignment, then I found a piece of treasure!
items.content_html:
One night I was doing project planning and information gathering for my assignment, then I found a piece of treasure!

Such treasure has been kindly shared by Laura Ellis, the Little Miss Data, on her well-organized website. This project was initialized by Laura and her friend, Katherine who is a school teacher. It starts with students collecting their own data. And then both students and mentors create various types of images, provides a lot of interesting visualizations.

Different from general datasets, this specific project dataset collects interesting variables like self-esteem, horoscope, psychology factors (intravert or extravert; optimist or pessmisit), Superpower and more.

With the power of Tableau, I'm able to have some quick insight on this data.


In this workseet, I want to have a view of how the distribution is like in terms of Career vs Students' horosocopes and their chosen subjects. It is very interesting to see some students who have the same horoscopes want to be in highly simliar industries regardless of their genders.

In above visualization, I want to see the relationship between Gender and Students' desired Superpower. With a quick glance at this chart, I have to say, flying is really a top skill! Also, from this superpower, I can see at least one task at Data Cleansing stage - conslidate multiple levels of factor that point to the same thing into one, and remove the case sensitivity in variable values. For example, some students write "Flying" while some write "fly", they can both be "Flying".

In this Mosaic plot, I'm trying to obtain an insight of children self-esteem and the top two activities they spend time at. The plot is not very straightforward as it could be, because of the number of levels in both variables. However, this potentially can be solved by grouping self-esteem into 2 or 3 classes, which I will try later.

After the exploration, I found the data richness is much higher than I expected!

I could not carry out all analysis at one go given my busy schedule. However, this quick playaround has clearly indicated me some data cleansinig tasks and potential topics to be discussed in the future!

I highly recommend reading Laura's project posts. I was much inspired by them! If you are interested, please start with Data + Art STEAM Project: Initial Results.

items.title: NeptuneX
items.summary: I build this application by using R and Shiny to obtain better understanding…
items.content_html:
I build this application by using R and Shiny to obtain better understanding of my spending habit by using deconfidentialized data.

A live application can be run at my Shiny.io server NeptuneX.

items.title: Amazon is ON FIRE
items.summary: First page on the applicationThis is an assignment I finished recently (try the…
items.content_html:
This is an assignment I finished recently (try the full application at DATA423_Assignment2).

In this assignment, we were required to pick one out of four fields to conduct our own researches and present results appropriately.

Being inspired (heart-broken) by the Amazon fire incident, I wanted to talk about forest in this project. At the end, I have chosen Multi-level/multi-class classification and finished my project by using the data from Te Uru Rākau|Forestry New Zealand.

I have learnt HEAPS from this assignment, including but not limitted to:

Statistics

Different imputation methods IN PRACTICE

I learnt a lot about imputation methods and their implementation via this project!

Various modelling methods IN PRACTICE

I learnt a lot about imputation methods and their implementation via this project!

A more appropriate Data Science project design

I knew Data Science involves Analysis (Statistical analysis) and programming (Computer Science). But I did not pay much attention to the beginning and the end sections.

After completing this project, now I know at the beginning of a project, you MUST understand the project background, propose the core question, and then find relevant data. EDA is not a simple concept either. It turns out to be very important because it shows the hidden data characteristics (if right methods are applied!), it would guide you what to do next (missing data? class imbalance?). EDA is a skilled techniques because it requires attention to details, so that you can see the messages by using the right forms.

I had been underestimated the power of EDA, thought it is a generic process to ALL projects. But in this journey, I found EDA is similar to DNA - a pair might share exactly the same content, but the chance is pretty low (good for confidence interval estimation thou!).

I'm happy that I no longer using the same EDA techniques over my different projects, but start tailoring and thinking over it for EACH project!

Shiny

Dynamic number of plots x googleVis Package

I used googleVis package before but not in a very dynmaic manner. In this project, the googleVis plots are generated dynamically!

This means if the dataset has one extra factor variable, there will be one extra barchart generated AUTOMATICALLY!

More flexibilities in Shiny

Previously, I write report text in server.R, then use the output function in ui.R for display purpose. However, I found out I can write the text in ui.R with HTML tags! This is great because it has reduced unreuqired code and efficient has improved, at the same time, it has further extended my HTML skill!

Keep in mind of what you are doing!

During the development, my modelling methods were 'not' working when I tested in in Shiny application, thought they were working fine on local (with R session restarted).

I almost gave up on these modellings though it took me a while to write. But then I noticed I used the wrong outcome variable to these methods! After correcting the formulas to use the right outcome variables, everything RAN!

Next time I will write down the question on a piece of paper to remind myself what I am trying to solve so that I would not be lost because of heavy and intensive development.
